conclusion: A missile is launched to intercept an aircraft flying at 20,000m altitude. The missile has mass m = 100 kg, initially accelerates vertically at 10g (100 m/s²), after reaching 5,000m altitude, changes its thrust direction to angle θ where cos(θ) = 1/11, has constant thrust throughout the flight, air resistance and mass change are negligible.
Let's break this into phases and determine the key unknowns.
During this phase, the missile accelerates straight up with a = 10g = 100 m/s².
Calculating thrust during vertical ascent: F = m(a + g) = 100 kg × (100 m/s² + 10 m/s²) = 11,000 N. So the thrust remains constant at 11,000 N throughout the flight.
Using the kinematic equation for displacement: h = ½at², 5,000m = ½ × 100 m/s² × t², t² = 100s², t = 10s.
The velocity at 5,000m can be calculated: v = at = 100 m/s² × 10s = 1,000 m/s.
After reaching 5,000m, the thrust direction changes to angle θ where cos(θ) = 1/11.
Determining the acceleration components: The horizontal component of thrust: Fx = F·cos(θ) = 11,000 N × (1/11) = 1,000 N.
Using the Pythagorean identity: sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1, sin²(θ) = 1 - cos²(θ) = 1 - (1/11)² = 1 - 1/121 = 120/121, sin(θ) = √(120/121) = √120/11.
The vertical component of thrust: Fy = 11,000 N × (√120/11) = 1,000 N × √120.
Calculating acceleration components: For the horizontal acceleration: ax = Fx/m = 1,000 N / 100 kg = 10 m/s².
For the vertical acceleration: ay = (Fy - mg)/m = (1,000 N × √120 - 100 kg × 10 m/s²)/100 kg, ay = 10√120 m/s² - 10 m/s² = 10(√120 - 1) m/s².
The thrust force generated by the rocket engine is F = 11,000 N.
The horizontal acceleration magnitude is: ax = 10 m/s².
The vertical acceleration magnitude is: ay = 10(√120 - 1) m/s² ≈ 10(10.954 - 1) m/s² ≈ 99.54 m/s². In radical form: ay = 10(√120 - 1) m/s².
